common_queries.query: What is the yield strength of A106 Grade B?
common_queries.answer: ASTM A106 Grade B has a minimum yield strength of 35 ksi (241 MPa) and a minimum tensile strength of 60 ksi (415 MPa).

common_queries.query: Does 4140 steel meet NACE MR0175 requirements?
common_queries.answer: AISI 4140 can meet NACE MR0175 requirements for sour service, but ONLY if properly heat treated to achieve a maximum hardness of 22 HRC (248 HBW). In the quenched and tempered condition at 400°F, 4140 typically exceeds 50 HRC and would NOT be compliant. For sour service, 4140 must be normalized and tempered or quenched and tempered with a minimum tempering temperature of 1150°F to achieve the required hardness.

common_queries.query: Compare A53 and A106 for high-temperature service
common_queries.answer:
For high-temperature service, ASTM A106 is preferred over ASTM A53:

• A106 is specifically designed for high-temperature service up to 1000°F
• A106 Grade B has tighter chemistry controls (lower phosphorus/sulfur limits)
• A106 requires hydrostatic testing at higher pressures
• A53 is intended for ordinary uses (steam, water, gas lines) at lower temperatures
• A106 is always seamless, while A53 can be welded (Type E) or seamless (Type S)

For refinery and power plant high-temperature piping, A106 is the industry standard.

common_queries.query: Maximum allowable hardness for sour service?
common_queries.answer:
Per NACE MR0175/ISO 15156, the maximum allowable hardness for carbon and low-alloy steels in sour (H2S) service is:

• 22 HRC (Rockwell C)
• 248 HBW (Brinell)
• 250 HV (Vickers)

This applies when H2S partial pressure exceeds 0.05 psi (0.3 kPa) in aqueous environments. Weld heat-affected zones must also meet this requirement.

common_queries.query: What is ASTM A333 Grade 6 used for?
common_queries.answer:
ASTM A333 Grade 6 is used for low-temperature service piping, specifically:

• Minimum service temperature: -50°F (-46°C)
• Applications: Cryogenic piping, LNG facilities, cold climate pipelines
• Yield strength: 35 ksi minimum
• Tensile strength: 60 ksi minimum
• Requires Charpy impact testing at -50°F

Grade 6 is the most commonly specified grade for low-temperature carbon steel pipe in the oil and gas industry.
